item.title: Analysing Belgian Politics with Wikipedia
item.description: Another source of data is Wikipedia. I came across this article, and decided to see what I could obtain using it on Belgian politics. Many thanks to the authors of the MZES (Mannheim Zentrum für Europäische Sozialforschung)! Gentlepersons, load your libraries: ## Packages pkgs <- c( "devtools", "ggnetwork", "igraph", "intergraph", "tidyverse", "rvest", "devtools", "magrittr", "plotly", "RColorBrewer", "colorspace", "lubridate", "networkD3", "pageviews", "readr", "wikipediatrend", "WikipediR", "WikidataR", "glue" ) ## Install uninstalled packages lapply(pkgs[!

item.title: friends in politics
item.description: In the last post we tried hard to find out all the Twitter handles of our current parliamentarians. A number of interesting analyses can be done with the texts they tweet. But the legislature is quite young and since there still is no federal government and that we are in summer break there are not enough tweets to have interesting analyses at this moment. One of the things we can analyse now are the links on Twitter between members of parliament as demonstrated by the excellent blog posts/code of Markus Konrad starting here
